questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=4 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=3 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex BC^2+CA^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex 4^2+3^2=AB^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2=16+9=25, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{25}=5. endlatex]Thus [startlatexinline AB=5 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline B endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline AB=6 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=10 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline B endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex BC^2+AB^2=CA^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex BC^2+6^2=10^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline]:  [startlatex BC^2+36=100, endlatex] [startlatex BC^2=100-36=64, endlatex] [startlatex BC=\sqrt{64}=8. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline BC=8 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]. generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex CA^2+BC^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex CA^2+12^2=15^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]:  [startlatex CA^2+144=225, endlatex] [startlatex CA^2=225-144=81, endlatex] [startlatex CA=\sqrt{81}=9. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline CA=9 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline A endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline A endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+CA^2=BC^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex AB^2+16^2=20^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2+256=400, endlatex] [startlatex AB^2=400-256=144, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{144}=12. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline AB=12 endlatexinline] cm

By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+CA^2=BC^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex 25^2+60^2=BC^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline]:  [startlatex BC^2=625+3600=4225, endlatex] [startlatex BC=\sqrt{4225}=65. endlatex]Thus [startlatexinline BC=65 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=16 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=63 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex BC^2+CA^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex 16^2+63^2=AB^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2=256+3969=4225, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{4225}=65. endlatex]Thus [startlatexinline AB=65 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline AB=61 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline BC=60 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex CA^2+BC^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex CA^2+60^2=61^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]:  [startlatex CA^2+3600=3721, endlatex] [startlatex CA^2=3721-3600=121, endlatex] [startlatex CA=\sqrt{121}=11. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline CA=11 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline B endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=84 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=85 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline B endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+BC^2=CA^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex AB^2+84^2=85^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2+7056=7225, endlatex] [startlatex AB^2=7225-7056=169, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{169}=13. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline AB=13 endlatexinline] cm
